message_1: A spaceship travels at 0.8c relative to Earth. Another spaceship travels at 0.6c relative to the first spaceship. What is the velocity of the second spaceship relative to Earth, according to relativistic velocity addition?
message_2:
To find the velocity of the second spaceship relative to Earth, we will use the relativistic velocity addition formula:

v = (v1 + v2) / (1 + (v1 * v2) / c^2)

where v1 is the velocity of the first spaceship relative to Earth (0.8c), v2 is the velocity of the second spaceship relative to the first spaceship (0.6c), and c is the speed of light.

v = (0.8c + 0.6c) / (1 + (0.8c * 0.6c) / c^2)

v = (1.4c) / (1 + (0.48c^2) / c^2)

v = (1.4c) / (1 + 0.48)

v = (1.4c) / 1.48

So, the velocity of the second spaceship relative to Earth is approximately 0.9459c.
